Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Combinatorial Biomaterials for Endothelial Cell Mechanobiology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER award by the Biomaterials program in the Materials Research Division to University of South Florida is to study combinatorial biomaterials that mimic the mechanical and chemical properties of the basement matrix for high throughput studies of endothelial cell mechanotransduction. Endothelial cells form the lining of blood vessels and other tissues by adhering to the basal lamina and organizing into monolayers. Due to the complex microenvironment of these specialized tissues, mechanotransduction (translation of mechanical inputs into biochemical signals) mechanisms are central to regulating endothelial cell homeostasis and progression towards disease states. A combinatorial approach is uniquely able to accurately recapitulate the range of natural physiology and rapidly analyze the interactions of multiple matrix-mediated mechanical and chemical signals in endothelial cell mechanobiology. The expected outcomes of the research program proposed here will provide the necessary tools and fill the gap in the current understanding of how mechanical properties and forces are sensed, translated into biochemical signals, and integrated with other pathways that control endothelial cell fate. Concurrently, hands-on tutorials, based on the underlying biophysical principles of mechanotransduction, will be developed for a high school Biomedical Sciences curriculum expected to encourage diversity in STEM disciplines. These tutorials will be designed and delivered by a team of high school students and teachers collaborating with University of South Florida faculty and graduate and undergraduate students. The proposed research and outreach activities will provide students opportunities to interact with researchers from a variety of disciplines and share their research with the community.


Endothelial cells organize on a thin protein matrix and form the lining of every blood vessel in the body. The present proposal integrates research and education activities designed to investigate the complex set of signals that direct the regulation and disease progression of these specialized tissues. Specifically, mechanisms of mechanotransduction (the process of translating mechanical inputs into biochemical signals) from forces caused by blood flow and tissue stiffness will be studied. A combinatorial approach will be used which enables high throughput studies to rapidly analyze the interactions of multiple mechanical and chemical signals. These studies will develop new combinatorial materials and are expected to provide an understanding of how mechanical properties and forces control endothelial cell behavior. Furthermore, the findings of this work will enable the design of materials that template the structure and guide the organization in engineered tissues for repair and replacement. Hands-on tutorials, based on the principles of mechanotransduction elucidated by this research, will be developed for a high school Biomedical Sciences curriculum expected to encourage diversity in STEM disciplines. These tutorials will be designed and delivered by a team of high school students and teachers collaborating with University of South Florida faculty and graduate and undergraduate students. This collaborative learning approach will enhance the training of students across multiple levels.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The basement membrane of epithelial tissues is a complex microenvironment with unique mechanical and chemical properties that guide cell fate. However, little is known about the synergistic signals of this microenvironment that direct from the outside-in the formation of cellular barriers such as the endothelial lining of blood vessels. The research purpose of this project was to engineer a combinatorial biomaterials platform for high throughput investigations of endothelial cell mechanotransduction and their relation to pathways that lead to disease or will enable vascularization of engineered tissues. A gradient crosslinking and surface functionalization fabrication strategy for silicone elastomer networks was investigated as a flexible high throughput platform for receptor-mediated cell adhesion and mechanotransduction signaling.  

 

Intellectual Merit: Two key achievements were realized: (1) the development of methods to fabricate combinatorial materials with programmable continuous variations in surface chemistry on substrates with orthogonally varied elastic moduli that vary within physiological ranges of stiffness for tissues; and (2) the advancement of methods to accurately describe the bulk and surface elastic properties of elastomeric materials with spatially regulated crosslink density. Specifically, new nanoindentation and macroscopic compression methods for spatially mapping the modulus in elastic gradient materials were developed. In addition, protein and cell function assays and automated microscopy methods were adapted for high throughput studies. These outcomes enabled fundamental investigations of cell adhesion strength and cell phenotype responses to wide ranges of combined mechanical and biochemical cues. For example, the individual and combined roles of surface chemistry and matrix stiffness in modulating protein conformation, cell morphology and adhesion strength were analyzed, and we found that controlling endothelial cell-matrix adhesions revealed an inverse relationship to cell-cell junction formation. Moreover, these developments helped to initiate other projects on stimuli-responsive biomaterials, engineered extracellular matrices and surface functionalization.

 

Broader Impacts: This project also supported significant training and professional development efforts. Five graduate students competed research theses with the direct support of this award. Their research training and career development were acquired in a diverse and interdisciplinary environment that crossed the boundaries of polymer chemistry, cell biology, mechanics and biomedical engineering. Beyond research, their training included career mentoring, entrepreneurship, critical thinking, technical writing and oral communication skills. This training also involved 11 undergraduate researchers over the course of the project. All the trainees aided the PI in numerous outreach and educational initiatives. These efforts, designed to foster excitement in K12 students about STEM disciplines, have included summer long research programs to develop lab demonstrations for high schools, lesson planning with the Superhero Training Network for elementary school curriculums, and hosting groups of home schooled students for interactive lab demonstrations.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/13/2017
Modified by: Nathan D Gallant
